is the biggest city in the province of

, the Netherlands. Although Emmen is not a particularly interesting destination for travellers, it's well known in the Netherlands for its biggest attraction: the zoo.

The town consists of the main suburbs

value: de Rietlanden, Bargeres, Delftlanden, Parc Sandur, Angelslo, Emmerhout, Emmermeer and Barger-Oosterveld.

Some smaller suburbs are Noordbarge, Zuidbarge, Westenesch and Weerdinge. Noordbarge and Zuidbarge are the oldest suburbs, but they used to be independent villages.

Emmen has two train stations, the central one and one in the south of town (Emmen Zuid). From

and change trains there. The journey will take about 2.5 hours.

Many bus lines connect Emmen to all destinations in the area. You'll find the main bus terminal across the street from the central train station.
You can rent a bicycle at the railway station. Next to the railway station is the busstation. Busses go from here to the suburbs, some surrounding villages and

.

Most visitors will come here for the zoo, however, which is an easy 15 min. walk from the train station with directions provided along the way. If that's too far, you can take a bus to the
, from where it's about 100m to the zoo entrance. Ask at the bus

value: Young giraffes in the zoo, the town's main attraction.
hours=10AM to 4:30PM or later, depending on season

content=The main zoo in the Northern Netherlands and for decades one of the largest zoos in the Netherlands. A bit outdated, it suffered losses in recent years but all in all this place remains well worth a visit, as it has a nice collection of animals in good habitats.
There are a number of monumental building in the city centre, including several churches. The most notable one is the
, with a Roman tower originating in the 12th century. The

seems a lot older than it actually is due to its design, but originates in 1949. It is nonetheless a national monument. The 1878 synagogue still has its original interiors, making it unique in the wide region. Also, two Saxon farm buildings remain in the city centre, one on the market square, now housing a café.

Emmen has one of the largest shopping malls of the northern part of the Netherlands and a pleasant city centre with a good range of shops. Many people from the region in fact prefer Emmen over larger
for a day of shopping, as it's considered more cosy.

content=The place to go for a curry, as this Indian restaurant gets raving reviews. The service is friendly.

content=Pancake restaurants are not only loved by kids. This place is popular with young and old alike and serves a wide variety of pancakes, but traditional Dutch poffertjes (fluffy, mini-pancakes) and wafers as well.
content=The menu is nothing out of the ordinary, but the food is well-prepared and it's good quality for money. They serve a range of bistro style food, salades and sandwiches for lunch.

In the mainstreet of Emmen (hoofdstraat) are multiple bars and restaurants. The
is probably the most popular bar. The most popular nightclub-like bar is de

value: is a professional football club playing at the second highest level in the Netherlands. For most matches tickets are free purchasable at the stadium at matchday.
is a professional handball club playing at the highest level in the Netherlands. E&O became 5 times Dutch national champions.

Emmen lies on the southernmost tip of a chain hills called the Hondsrug (Dog Ridge), an area with many forests that is popular with cyclists and ramblers alike. This part of the country is also well known for its "hunebedden" (dolmens), Stone Age burial chambers. Some of these lie within the built-up area of Emmen itself.

By contrast, to the south and east of Emmen lie the completely flat lands known as the peat colonies.
